fields.label: STS Token
fields.help_text: Security Token Service (STS) is a web service that enables you to request temporary, limited-privilege credentials for AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) users.

fields.label: Service Account Email Address
fields.help_text: The email address assigned to the Google Compute Engine service account.

fields.label: Project
fields.help_text: The Project ID is the GCE assigned identification. It is often constructed as three words or two words followed by a three-digit number. Examples: project-id-000 and another-project-id

fields.label: RSA Private Key
fields.help_text: Paste the contents of the PEM file associated with the service account email.

fields.label: Subscription ID
fields.help_text: Subscription ID is an Azure construct, which is mapped to a username.

fields.label: Azure Cloud Environment
fields.help_text: Environment variable AZURE_CLOUD_ENVIRONMENT when using Azure GovCloud or Azure stack.

fields.label: Host (Authentication URL)
fields.help_text: The host to authenticate with.  For example, https://openstack.business.com/v2.0/

fields.label: Domain Name
fields.help_text: OpenStack domains define administrative boundaries. It is only needed for Keystone v3 authentication URLs. Refer to the documentation for common scenarios.

fields.label: Region Name
fields.help_text: For some cloud providers, like OVH, region must be specified

fields.label: Red Hat Ansible Automation Platform
fields.help_text: Red Hat Ansible Automation Platform base URL to authenticate with.

fields.label: Username
fields.help_text: Red Hat Ansible Automation Platform username id to authenticate as.This should not be set if an OAuth token is being used.

fields.label: OAuth Token
fields.help_text: An OAuth token to use to authenticate with.This should not be set if username/password are being used.

fields.label: Satellite 6 URL
fields.help_text: Enter the URL that corresponds to your Red Hat Satellite 6 server. For example, https://satellite.example.org

fields.label: Host (Authentication URL)
fields.help_text: The host to authenticate with.

fields.label: CA File
fields.help_text: Absolute file path to the CA file to use (optional)

fields.label: VCenter Host
fields.help_text: Enter the hostname or IP address that corresponds to your VMware vCenter.

fields.label: GPG Public Key
fields.help_text: GPG Public Key used to validate content signatures.

fields.label: Centrify Tenant URL
fields.help_text: Centrify Tenant URL

fields.label: Centrify API User
fields.help_text: Centrify API User, having necessary permissions as mentioned in support doc

fields.label: Centrify API Password
fields.help_text: Password of Centrify API User with necessary permissions

fields.label: OAuth2 Application ID
fields.help_text: Application ID of the configured OAuth2 Client (defaults to 'awx')

fields.label: OAuth2 Scope
fields.help_text: Scope of the configured OAuth2 Client (defaults to 'awx')

metadata.label: Account Name
metadata.help_text: Local system account or Domain account name enrolled in Centrify Vault. eg. (root or DOMAIN/Administrator)

metadata.label: System Name
metadata.help_text: Machine Name enrolled with in Centrify Portal

credential_types.name: CyberArk AIM Central Credential Provider Lookup

metadata.label: Object Query
metadata.help_text: Lookup query for the object. Ex: Safe=TestSafe;Object=testAccountName123

metadata.label: Reason
metadata.help_text: Object request reason. This is only needed if it is required by the object's policy.

natural_key.name: CyberArk AIM Central Credential Provider Lookup

metadata.label: Secret Identifier
metadata.help_text: The identifier for the secret e.g., /some/identifier

metadata.label: Secret Version
metadata.help_text: Used to specify a specific secret version (if left empty, the latest version will be used).

fields.label: Server URL
fields.help_text: The URL to the HashiCorp Vault

fields.label: Token
fields.help_text: The access token used to authenticate to the Vault server

fields.label: CA Certificate
fields.help_text: The CA certificate used to verify the SSL certificate of the Vault server

fields.label: AppRole role_id
fields.help_text: The Role ID for AppRole Authentication

fields.label: AppRole secret_id
fields.help_text: The Secret ID for AppRole Authentication

fields.label: Namespace name (Vault Enterprise only)
fields.help_text: Name of the namespace to use when authenticate and retrieve secrets

fields.label: Kubernetes role
fields.help_text: The Role for Kubernetes Authentication. This is the named role, configured in Vault server, for AWX pod auth policies. see https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/auth/kubernetes#configuration

fields.label: Path to Auth
fields.help_text: The Authentication path to use if one isn't provided in the metadata when linking to an input field. Defaults to 'approle'

fields.label: API Version
fields.help_text: API v1 is for static key/value lookups.  API v2 is for versioned key/value lookups.

metadata.label: Name of Secret Backend
metadata.help_text: The name of the kv secret backend (if left empty, the first segment of the secret path will be used).

metadata.label: Path to Secret
metadata.help_text: The path to the secret stored in the secret backend e.g, /some/secret/. It is recommended that you use the secret backend field to identify the storage backend and to use this field for locating a specific secret within that store. However, if you prefer to fully identify both the secret backend and one of its secrets using only this field, join their locations into a single path without any additional separators, e.g, /location/of/backend/some/secret.

metadata.label: Path to Auth
metadata.help_text: The path where the Authentication method is mounted e.g, approle

metadata.label: Key Name
metadata.help_text: The name of the key to look up in the secret.

metadata.label: Secret Version (v2 only)
metadata.help_text: Used to specify a specific secret version (if left empty, the latest version will be used).

fields.label: Server URL
fields.help_text: The URL to the HashiCorp Vault

fields.label: Token
fields.help_text: The access token used to authenticate to the Vault server

fields.label: CA Certificate
fields.help_text: The CA certificate used to verify the SSL certificate of the Vault server

fields.label: AppRole role_id
fields.help_text: The Role ID for AppRole Authentication

fields.label: AppRole secret_id
fields.help_text: The Secret ID for AppRole Authentication

fields.label: Namespace name (Vault Enterprise only)
fields.help_text: Name of the namespace to use when authenticate and retrieve secrets

fields.label: Kubernetes role
fields.help_text: The Role for Kubernetes Authentication. This is the named role, configured in Vault server, for AWX pod auth policies. see https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/auth/kubernetes#configuration

fields.label: Path to Auth
fields.help_text: The Authentication path to use if one isn't provided in the metadata when linking to an input field. Defaults to 'approle'

metadata.label: Path to Secret
metadata.help_text: The path to the secret stored in the secret backend e.g, /some/secret/. It is recommended that you use the secret backend field to identify the storage backend and to use this field for locating a specific secret within that store. However, if you prefer to fully identify both the secret backend and one of its secrets using only this field, join their locations into a single path without any additional separators, e.g, /location/of/backend/some/secret.

metadata.label: Path to Auth
metadata.help_text: The path where the Authentication method is mounted e.g, approle

metadata.label: Role Name
metadata.help_text: The name of the role used to sign.

metadata.label: Valid Principals
metadata.help_text: Valid principals (either usernames or hostnames) that the certificate should be signed for.

fields.label: Cloud Environment
fields.help_text: Specify which azure cloud environment to use.

metadata.label: Secret Name
metadata.help_text: The name of the secret to look up.

metadata.label: Secret Version
metadata.help_text: Used to specify a specific secret version (if left empty, the latest version will be used).

fields.label: Tenant
fields.help_text: The tenant e.g. "ex" when the URL is https://ex.secretservercloud.com

fields.label: Top-level Domain (TLD)
fields.help_text: The TLD of the tenant e.g. "com" when the URL is https://ex.secretservercloud.com

metadata.label: Secret Path
metadata.help_text: The secret path e.g. /test/secret1

fields.label: Secret Server URL
fields.help_text: The Base URL of Secret Server e.g. https://myserver/SecretServer or https://mytenant.secretservercloud.com

fields.label: Username
fields.help_text: The (Application) user username

fields.label: Password
fields.help_text: The corresponding password

metadata.label: Secret ID
metadata.help_text: The integer ID of the secret

metadata.label: Secret Field
metadata.help_text: The field to extract from the secret

fields.label: Galaxy Server URL
fields.help_text: The URL of the Galaxy instance to connect to.

fields.label: Auth Server URL
fields.help_text: The URL of a Keycloak server token_endpoint, if using SSO auth.

fields.label: API Token
fields.help_text: A token to use for authentication against the Galaxy instance.

credential_types.name: OpenShift or Kubernetes API Bearer Token

fields.label: OpenShift or Kubernetes API Endpoint
fields.help_text: The OpenShift or Kubernetes API Endpoint to authenticate with.

natural_key.name: OpenShift or Kubernetes API Bearer Token

fields.label: Authentication URL
fields.help_text: Authentication endpoint for the container registry.

fields.label: Password or Token
fields.help_text: A password or token used to authenticate with

fields.label: Privilege Escalation Method
fields.help_text: Specify a method for "become" operations. This is equivalent to specifying the --become-method Ansible parameter.

fields.label: Token
fields.help_text: This token needs to come from your profile settings in GitHub

fields.label: Token
fields.help_text: This token needs to come from your profile settings in GitLab

fields.label: Vault Identifier
fields.help_text: Specify an (optional) Vault ID. This is equivalent to specifying the --vault-id Ansible parameter for providing multiple Vault passwords.  Note: this feature only works in Ansible 2.4+.
